image.altText: A mother reading a book to her two children in bed

props.synopsis: As school attendance and attention wanes, teachers say small changes at home can make a big difference during school hours.

title.children: Why taking their screen away at night might be the best thing you can do for your child's school grades

image.altText: Cars rush past a modern building fronted with opaque glass panels.

props.synopsis: Days after Tasmania's Liberal government cops flak over no funds being allocated to Launceston's promised heart centre in the state budget, Prime Minister Albanese announces the Federal government would foot the entire bill.

title.children: Federal government to foot entire bill for specialised heart centre in Tasmania's north

image.altText: A sign sits outside Launceston General Hospital.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's Health Department will appoint a senior doctor to conduct audits of patient death records across the health system from before 2019. It follows a report in June which found 29 deaths were never referred to the coroner when they should have been.

title.children: 'We haven't got this right': Tasmania to appoint senior doctor to audit patient death records

image.altText: Shane Navin with Glenn Evans in Mazda RX7

props.synopsis: Glenn Evans has told a Hobart court of the crash that killed fellow Targa Tasmania competitor Shane Navin in 2021. An inquest is examining four deaths in three separate Targa crashes in 2021 and 2022.

title.children: 'I felt the car start to slide': Targa competitor recounts crash that killed his co-driver

image.altText: A man in a cap and waterproof clothes leaning in to look closely at moss growing on a tree trunk with a hand lens.

props.synopsis: Des Callaghan has travelled the world photographing mosses, and describes Tasmania as a "hotspot".

title.children: Tasmania is a hotspot for mosses, those 'overlooked botanical beauties'

image.altText: A man in a white shirt looks towards the camera.

props.synopsis: A former captain of Australia's Olympic rowing team pinned his ex-wife down while wearing black rubber gloves and had her in "fear for her life" during an assault he has pleaded guilty to, a Tasmanian court has heard.

title.children: Former Olympic rower wore 'black rubber gloves' during assault of ex-wife, court told

image.altText: A woman leans on a large trolley with multiple suitcases on it, and looks on

props.synopsis: Australians trying to leave Lebanon as hostilities between Israel and Hezbollah increase are running out of options, as flights are cancelled and the IDF's top commander highlights the possibility that troops will cross the border.

title.children: 'Mum, you have to come back': Aussies stranded in Lebanon as possible Israeli ground invasion looms

image.altText: Anthony Albanese looks slightly cross while giving a press conference.

props.synopsis: Negative gearing and capital gains tax rules have sat in Labor's bottom drawer since the party's bruising 2019 election defeat. Now, with Labor's primary vote slipping in the polls, there's speculation they could be back on the table.

title.children: 'We'll run a scare campaign': Inside the politics surrounding Labor's negative gearing dilemma

image.altText: A drawing showing a wide path leading onto a bridge

props.synopsis: Two years ago, the Tasmanian government released concept designs for wider pathways for pedestrians and cyclists on the Tasman Bridge. Now, the government says it cannot be done without spending significantly more money than it budgeted.

title.children: Did you miss? 📣 Hobart's Tasman Bridge pathway widening plan scrapped

image.altText: Smoke billows over a residential area

props.synopsis: Israel's military chief tells troops air strikes in Lebanon will continue in order to destroy Hezbollah infrastructure and to prepare the way for a possible ground operation by Israeli forces.

title.children: Air strikes on Lebanon a precursor to possible ground operations, Israeli military chief says

image.altText: Volodymyr Zelenskyy speaks in front of a green marbled wall.

props.synopsis: Russia's plans to "torment millions of Ukrainians" by destroying the country's power infrastructure threatens to cause a nuclear catastrophe that could reach beyond Ukraine's borders, Volodymyr Zelenskyy warns world leaders at the UN General Assembly.

title.children: Zelenskyy warns of 'nuclear disaster' under Russian plans to strike power plants

image.altText: The former foster father of Kaydence Mills holds a photo album of the toddler.

props.synopsis: Court documents suggest staff missed warning signs about the toddler's whereabouts in 2018, when she had already been dead a year.

title.children: 'This is going to happen again': Queensland toddler dead for two years before authorities realised she was missing

image.altText: A horse buggy going past a fire.

props.synopsis: As the price of copper surges globally, armed criminal syndicates are stripping the country bare in search of easy cash.

title.children: 'It's fast cash': The hunt for a metal so lucrative that thieves risk electrocution to steal it is crippling South Africa

image.altText: A gas plant.

props.synopsis: Closing the nuclear-energy electricity gap with gas power will cost $70 billion, boost emissions by 325 million tonnes, and increase gas usage through to 2035 by five times annual production, according to new Labor analysis.

title.children: Dutton's plan for nuclear power will open up a $70 billion gas gap, Labor says

image.altText: A tank fires a large fiery blast in a field.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian Ambassador Vasyl Myroshnychenko says if Australia's older tanks were eventually donated his country "will put them good to use".

title.children: Fresh hope Ukraine will soon receive ageing Australian Abrams tanks as Defence reviews military support

image.altText: Composite image - easey street

props.synopsis: A man says he won't fight extradition to Melbourne to face charges of murdering two women in 1977, sparking 'disbelief' from the family of one victim.

title.children: Lawyer for Easey Street accused Perry Kouroumblis says he will agree to extradition

image.altText: Zikai wears clear rimmed glasses and a grey jumper and stands beside white curtains looking off camera.

props.synopsis: A Melbourne university has been asked to explain itself after suggesting it could forcibly acquire a group of apartments to expand its campus if their owners didn't agree to sell.

title.children: Homeowners anxious after major university suggests it could forcibly acquire their apartments

image.altText: An older woman with blonde hair and a white blazer looks at the camera in a composite image with police officers

props.synopsis: An ABC investigation uncovers allegations of bullying, sexism and a dangerous lack of support within the ranks of NSW Police, which officers say is driving hundreds of officers out of the force.

title.children: Bullying, sexism and 'toxic' culture claims levelled at Australia's biggest police force

image.altText: cranes in beijing

props.synopsis: China has announced a broad suite of stimulus measures, but analysts are sceptical about whether they are enough to kickstart a sluggish economy.

title.children: 'Too little, too late': New China stimulus blitz faces scepticism from economists

image.altText: Williams wears black rimmed glasses at his home, looking outward to some greenery

props.synopsis: Kim Williams says the ABC is "eager to restore" a bureau in Beijing after the last correspondent was forced to leave in 2020.

title.children: ABC chair calls for return of China correspondent to mark 'profound' importance of Beijing on world stage

image.altText: A close-up shot of a shopping trolley full of groceries in a supermarket with a woman behind bagging apples.

props.synopsis: Basic grocery items are still cheaper at Aldi when compared with Coles and Woolworths, according to consumer group Choice, which has again found little price difference between the two major grocers.

title.children: Choice report finds cost of basket of goods at Coles and Woolworths is 'almost identical'

image.altText: A man smiles and waves at supporters through the barred window of a red bus.

props.synopsis: After his failed attempt to take power by storming parliament with armed supporters in 2000, George Speight was initially sentenced to death by hanging but that was later commuted to a life sentence.

title.children: 'Tell the truth': Now George Speight is free, Fijians want answers about his failed coup

image.altText: Houses under construction on a bright, sunny day

props.synopsis: The policy that just won't quit is back. Will Labor revisit its 2016 and 2019 election policies?

title.children: We're talking about negative gearing again, but why is it such a big deal?

image.altText: Casey candidate Jamel Kaur Singh next to a campaign sign of her with racist graffiti.

props.synopsis: A council candidate in Melbourne's outer south-east has been left shaken after her campaign sign was vandalised with racist slurs. Experts are concerned such abuse could deter diverse women from entering politics.

title.children: 'I am what Australia looks like': Melbourne council candidate hits back after racist vandalism

image.altText: A woman in yellow jumper holding shopping bag faces a supermarket shelf full of colourful wrapped foods.

props.synopsis: Many of us are looking to save money at the grocery shop, but it's not always that simple. Here are a few pointers that could make a difference.

title.children: Tips and tricks for shrinking your supermarket spending

image.altText: Two investigators wearing full PPE and a police officer standing in the background at a taped off property.

props.synopsis: Ask a forensic scientist to recommend a crime show that accurately portrays their work and they'll probably tell you they can't. So, how do they actually help solve crimes?

title.children: From skulking around crime scenes to solving crimes solo: What popular TV shows get wrong about forensic science

image.altText: A photo of a contraceptive pill packet for a story about why women are turning away from the pill.

props.synopsis: The NSW government says a trial contraceptive pill scheme will be made permanent from this Saturday. It allows women who use the pill to get a 12-month refill from a pharmacist without a new script.

title.children: Access to the pill is about to get easier in NSW. Here's why

image.altText: A dingo surrounded by dried grass

props.synopsis: Farmers welcome a state government decision to extend an "unprotection order" on dingoes and wild dogs, but environmental advocates say the native predators are a vital part of the ecosystem.

title.children: Farmers get green light to keep killing dingoes in east Victoria

image.altText: An emu walking on a red gravel track in an arid daytime area with one leg lifted.

props.synopsis: Emus might look ungainly when they pick up pace, but they’re actually very efficient runners, a new study suggests.

title.children: Why running emus keep one foot on the ground

image.altText: A close up of a medicinal cannabis flower showing the THC tricones.

props.synopsis: Palliative patients in regional areas are needed for a new trial into medicinal cannabis, which could help transform access to end-of-life care research.

title.children: Telehealth technology to bring medicinal cannabis trial to regional Queensland palliative patients

image.altText: Michael Matthews, Ben O'Connor, Jay Vine, Grace Brown, Brodie Chapman and Ruby Roseman-Ganon on a podium with gold medals

props.synopsis: The amazing Grace Brown farewell tour has hit another highlight with the cycling great helping Australia snatch gold in the mixed team time trial at the world championships in Switzerland.

title.children: Brown farewell tour continues with another gold for Australia

image.altText: Liz Watson and Sophie Garbin celebrate Australia's win over England.

props.synopsis: With the series on the line, the world champion Diamonds rebound from their second-Test loss to triumph 69-56 against the Roses in Bendigo.

title.children: Australia claims series honours against England with clinical victory in final Test

image.altText: Adelaide Crows' Jess Allan competes for the ball in the ruck with Tahlia Hickie of the Brisbane Lions in AFLW.

props.synopsis: Jess Allan and Jade Ellenger embody the Crows' and Lions' strategies for remaining two of the AFLW's top teams, as they prepare to face off in another blockbuster clash on Sunday.

title.children: As AFLW behemoths go head-to-head, how have Adelaide and Brisbane stayed on top?

image.altText: Joe Daniher celebrates a goal as Nick Blakey looks on

props.synopsis: Joe Daniher will have a major say on whether Brisbane can claim its first premiership since 2004 when he lines up in the grand final on Saturday. It is a role he came very close to playing for the Lions's grand final opponents, Sydney.

title.children: How Brisbane's potential grand final gamebreaker Joe Daniher slipped out of Sydney's grasp twice
